FacilityName: HUNTSMAN LLC -  PORT NECHES PERFORMANCE PRODUCTS

_prev_prog_3.Description: E-4 Unit: This process area is composed of the E-4 Unit which produces products that are used in the metal working lubricants, electronics, floor polishes, agriculture and paper by reacting ammonia and ethylene oxide to produce ethanolamines. All the risk management program elements apply. The unit contains a storage facility, diking and process area detectors.

E-3, E-6: The OSP (Oxide Specialties Process) area has two units: E-3 and E-6. Both units react ethylene oxide with either nonylphenol or linear alcohols to form nonylphenolethoxylates and linear alcohol ethyoxylates which are used in industrial and household detergents, among other products. E-3 unit consists of 3 reactors and associated equipment to charge, react and store product which is non-hazardous. E-6 unit consists of 5 reactors and associated equipment. The E6 unit reacts ethylene oxide and sulfur dioxide to form isethionate.

F-4, F-6 and G-1, G-5, G-6: The F units manufacture ethylene oxide using ethylene and oxygen as reactants. The G units react ethylene oxide and water for ethylene glycol (see Executive Summary for uses of ethylene glycol). G-1 unit receives the cycle water bleed streams produced in the F units and recovers antifreeze-grade glycol. The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemical and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity. RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture is ethane.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: DOUBLE MECHANICAL SEALS WITH SEAL POTS ON ALL PUMPS
_prev_prog_3.Description: The F-5, PO/MTBE process area consists of six sections which are the Feed Preparation, the Peroxidation Reaction, the Epoxidation Reaction, the TBA Purification, the PO Purification and the MTBE sections. The Feed Preparation Section consist of purification towers to purify and concentrate isobutane prior to charging the Peroxidation Section for reaction with a RMP non-covered chemical. The Epoxidation Section manufactures propylene oxide by reacting propylene with a RMP non-covered chemical. The Tertiary Butyl Alcohol section reclaims and purifies tertiary butyl alcohol for reuse; the Propylene Oxide Section does the same for propylene oxide. The MTBE section manufactures and purifies MTBE. The risk management program's elements apply to the F5 unit. The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemical and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity. RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are acetaldehyde, methane, butane and pentane. This process unit has associated diked storage tanks.

The Receiving and Shipping (R&S) area consists of product storage tanks; numerous truck and rail car loading/unloading facilities; and a barge and ship loading/unloading dock on the Neches River. Products that are stored in this area are pumped either to processing areas or shipped to customers. The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemical and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity. RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are hydrogen, methane, ethylene, propadiene, methyl formate, and vinyl acetylene.

The Utility Process Area utilizes chlorine for biological control of the water treatment facilities which includes raw water treatment and cooling water treatment. Chlorine is located at ten (10) separate locations.

The A3 Process Unit is divided into the following three sections.  The Furnace Section, the Cracked Gas Compression, Refrigeration and Tower sections, and the A3 offsites section. The Furnace section includes from the feed system through the furnaces up through the quench columns. The compression, refrigeration and tower section includes compression, refrigeration and separation equipment downstream of the furnace section as well as an acetylene hydrogenation unit. The A3 process unit includes tankage and ethylene metering skids associated with the A3 Process. All risk management process controls, mitigation, monitoring and detection systems apply to all units as noted below.  Only tankage has dikes and only tankage does not have a quench system and excess flow devices. Only the furnace unit does not have tandem seals.  The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non-RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity. RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are hydrogen, acetylene, propadiene, vinyl acetylene, pentane, and ethylacetylene.

E-7 Unit: This process area is composed of the E-7 Unit which produces products that are used in the metal working lubricants, floor polishes and paper by reacting ammonia and diethylene glycol on a continuous flow unit to produce morpholine and diglycolamine. All the risk management program elements apply. The unit contains a storage facility, diking, flares, and process area detectors.
G-2 unit reacts propylene oxide with water to form grades of propylene glycol (see Executive Summary). G-2 unit can also produce ethylene glycol.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HUNTSMAN LLC - Performance Products Site - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.  Huntsman Port Neches Performance Products (PNPP) Plant is committed to achieving excellence in environmental, health and safety. This is exemplified by the PNPP Site having earned the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) VPP Star award for excellence in safety performance.  The Huntsman PNPP Site  maintains a working Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which implements a series of steps to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and assures a well-trained work force.   The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals.  Huntsman PNPP Site participates with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Commission, Port Neches Fire Department and the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association to develop emergency response plans and participates in cooperative training with these agencies. The facility complies with all applicable codes and standards regarding operating and equipment safety. Huntsman has participated in the past with the Responsible Care; initiative ACC, is committed to the responsible management of chemicals and is an active participant in the International Standards Organization (ISO) 9002 quality management program.   The Director of Manufacturing - PNPP is responsible for implementation of the risk management program (RMP).

2.  Regulated Substances . The Oxides and Olefins Plant is located in Port Neches, Texas, on 2,400 acres bound by Highway 366 and Hogaboom Road.  The site began production in 1948 and was acquired by Huntsman in 1994. The site produces olefins, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, MTBE, ethylene glycol, ethanolamines, morpholine/DGA and surfactants derived from ethylene oxide.  The PNPP Site is divided into nine (9) process areas.  The first area contains unit E4.  The second area contains the Oxide Specialty process units E3 and E6.  The third ar

ea contains ethylene oxide units F4 and F6 and glycol units G1, G5 and G6.  The fourth area contains the PO/MTBE unit known as F5.  Receiving and Shipping (R&S)is the fifth area.  The sixth area is Utilities. The seventh area is ethylene unit A3.  The eighth area is E7 and the ninth area is G2. Huntsman's PNPP Site has eighteen (18) regulated flammables and seven(7) regulated toxics at the facility.

The eighteen (18) flammable substances are:

Ethylene - Product used to manufacture polyethylene grocery bags, wraps and machine parts, and as a raw material for other ethylene based products (ethylene glycol-antifreeze, ethanol amines-shaving creams, hand lotions, furniture polishes, and dry-cleaning preparations, etc.)

Propylene - Product used to manufacture polypropylene materials such  films, clothesline and other kinds of rope and, in turn, is used as a raw material for other propylene based materials (propylene glycol-factory fill antifreeze and propylene oxide).

Isobutane - Raw material used to  manufacture propylene oxide and MTBE.

Propane and Ethane - Raw materials used to manufacture propylene and ethylene and are ingredients in natural gas.

Methane - Raw material and used for fuel and are ingredients of fuel used in plant

Butane, 1-Butene, 1,3-Butadiene, 2-Butene cis and trans, and Isoprene - Products used as raw materials in the manufacture of synthetic rubber for tires, and butyl rubber for films, coatings and carpet.

Isopentane, 1-Pentene, 2-Pentene (E) and (Z), 2-Methyl-1-butene, 3-methyl-1-butene - Products used as feed stocks for the manufacture of ethylene

The seven (7) toxic substances are:

Anhydrous and Aqueous Ammonia - Raw material used in water treatment and in the manufacture of amines.

Ethylene Diamine (EDA) - Product used to treat water.

Propylene Oxide (PO) - Product used in making polyurethane foams (cushions and dashboards)

Chlorine - Added to cooling water for treatment

Ethylene Oxide - Product used to manufacture ethylene glyco

l which is used for automotive antifreeze and polyester clothing.

Sulfur Dioxide - Raw material to be used in the production of sodium isethionate.

3.  General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.  Following is a brief summary of the elements that Huntsman's PNPP Site has implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by EPA as well as with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) PSM standard:

Process Safety Information
Huntsman's PNPP site maintains a compilation of current and accurate written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process.  This includes information pertaining to: 
Hazards of regulated substances:  For each regulated substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) which discusses the physical properties of the chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.
The technology of the process:  Includes a discussion of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure and analysis of consequences of deviation.
Equipment in the process:  Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design codes.

Process Hazard Analysis
Huntsman's PNPP Site has performed process hazard analysis on each process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the ways to minimize those hazards.  The PNPP Site utilizes the HAZOP methodology, a recognized and generally accepted method, for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process.  The PNPP Site assigns employees to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the specific process.  The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are implemented within a reasonable period of time.  Hur

ricanes and inclement weather are not investigated in the PHAs; however, Huntsman does have a Hurricane Procedure and implements this procedure under the threat of a hurricane and inclement weather.

Operating Procedures
Huntsman PNPP maintains written operating procedures that were developed in consultation with operators to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process.  The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards.  The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.

Training
Huntsman PNPP provides initial training as well as refresher training to employees to assure that the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained.  The training emphas safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  All operators receive periodic refresher training.  

Mechanical Integrity
Huntsman PNPP has developed written procedures for maintaining the operating components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown system controls, and pumps) through the mechanical integrity program.  The program is comprised of well-trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.

Management of Change
Huntsman PNPP has established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that, prior to any change, the following issues are considered:  the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety and health, any  modification to operating procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and any authorization requirements.  Employees involved in operating a process, as

well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are updated.

Pre-Startup Review
Huntsman PNPP performs pre-startup safety reviews when the addition of or a modification to the facility is made that is significant enough to require a major change in the process safety information or is deemed as requiring more review than the combination of  a Management of Change and Process Hazard Analysis.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.

Compliance Audit
Huntsman PNPP performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its Process Safety Management Program.  Teams comprised of employees, with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques, process safety and operating experience, conduct audits every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed and appropriate corrective actions are implemented and tracked until resolved.  

Incident Investigation
Huntsman PNPP investigates any incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals.  The investigation is promptly conducted, commencing within 48 hours of any incident.  To perform the investigation, Huntsman PNPP has established a procedure to appoint an incident investigation team consisting of persons with the appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that addresses the incident, the factors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the in

cident investigation.  Huntsman PNPP has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations and to  document their resolution.  Finally, incident reports are reviewed with all affected personnel.

Employee Participation
Huntsman PNPP has developed a written action plan for employee participation in all aspects of its Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs.  Huntsman PNPP consults with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of PHAs and on the development of other elements of the Process Safety Management Program.  Huntsman PNPP ensures that all employees have access to PHAs and all other process safety management information.

Hot Work Permit
Huntsman PNPP employs a hot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (hot work generally involves electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark producing operations).  If any hot work is performed near a covered process, Huntsman PNPP issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed.  Hot work permits are kept on file until the work is complete.

Contractors
Huntsman PNPP has developed procedures for selecting and ensuring that contractors are competent and knowledgeable and can safely perform their work.  Huntsman PNPP provides information to contractors about the hazards that may be present in the work area and has developed appropriate safe work practices.  Huntsman PNPP also evaluates the safety performance and programs of the contractors as a part of their continued employment.

4.  5 Year Accident History.  The PNPP Site has had one (1) reportable RMP incident in the last five years.  The incident involved a release of sulfur dioxide.  Three contractors/employees had minor injuries. There was no onsite property damage. There were no off-site impacts

.

5.  Emergency Response Program.  Huntsman has a written emergency response program that contains procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release of a regulated substance.  These procedures include steps for informing the public, proper first aid and medical treatment, the proper use of emergency equipment and emergency response training for emergency response employees who perform emergency response duties and to local emergency responders who may be called to assist in emergency response.   The emergency response plan is reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  Huntsman is actively involved with informing local stakeholders about hazardous substances stored and processed on site.  Huntsman  participates with the Jefferson County LEPC, Sabine Neches Chiefs Association and Port Neches Fire Department  in assisting local officials in the development of emergency procedures to identify resources, chemicals, contacts and material safety data sheets for participating companies.  The Team Leader of Emergency Response is the emergency contact in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Coordinator for this plant is the designated alternate.  The initial response will be provided by Huntsman's on-site fire department.

6.  Planned changes to improve safety.  There are several planned improvements at the PNPP Site to reduce the on and offsite impacts.  Selected ongoing projects include improvements to upgrade fiber optic infrastructure, process control and instrumentation equipment.  There is continual commitment to implement changes, when identified, that will improve the safety of employees and neighbors of the PNPP Site as well as projects that enhance safety, environmental protection and protect neighbors from exposure to accidental releases.

7.  Reason for 2011 Re-submittal is voluntary update.
